concern: I'm in a MA program right now and we just started in-person learning. Until this week, I had been at my parents' house doing online school from there. While I'm definitely not the biggest proponent of online school, I was actually really enjoying life at home. I got to focus on doing readings and work without worrying about maintaining my own living space, I didn't have a commute to and from classes, and I really enjoyed hanging out with my family every day. Now I'm in a different city which is still pretty shut down from the pandemic, living alone, I can't see anyone, I haven't been able to focus on my coursework that much, and I just feel really *lonely* especially since the people in my cohort aren't keen on getting together due to the pandemic. Even though I absolutely love my program and what I'm studying, I'm starting to question if it's worth the lifestyle choices that are necessary (e.g., moving away from home, the job search being global rather than local). Now, I'm finding myself wishing the weeks would pass until I can go back during the break. I'm wondering if anyone else feels the same way and how they cope with it. I'm also wondering if moving away for grad school is that much better if there weren't a pandemic shutting everything down/limiting any social activities; especially since so many people refer to grad school as an isolating experience anyway.

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! I'm glad you're here. What would you like to talk about today?
Hey. I've been feeling really lonely and having a hard time adjusting to being in a new city for my grad program. It's just been tough without much social interaction due to the pandemic.
That sounds really challenging. What have been some of the hardest parts about adjusting to the new city for you?
client: I think the hardest part is just feeling isolated. I'm used to having my family around, and now it feels like I'm just here on my own without that support system.
It sounds like being away from your family and support system has been tough. What do you think life might look like if you felt more connected in your new city?
I guess if I felt more connected, I'd probably be more motivated and focused on my coursework. It might make the city feel a bit more like home instead of just a temporary place.
It sounds like feeling more connected could really enhance your experience and motivation. What small steps do you think you could take to start building that connection in your new environment?

Maybe I could start by reaching out to some classmates and see if anyone wants to do a virtual study group or something. I could also try exploring the city a bit more on my own, even if it's just going for walks to get to know the area better.

Those sound like great starting points. Based on what you said, possible options include organizing a virtual study group with classmates or planning regular walks to explore the city. How do you feel about setting a goal for one of these actions, and what might be some barriers you anticipate?

I feel pretty good about setting a goal, maybe starting with the virtual study group since it's a bit easier to manage. As for barriers, I'm worried about everyone being too busy or not interested, and I sometimes find it hard to motivate myself to explore alone.

Setting a goal for the virtual study group sounds like a manageable first step. To address potential barriers, you might consider reaching out to a few classmates individually to gauge interest, and perhaps set a specific day and time for the study sessions. For exploring, maybe you can set small, manageable goals, like visiting a new spot each week. How does that sound, and what might help you stay motivated?

That sounds like a solid plan, especially breaking down the exploration part into smaller goals. To stay motivated, maybe I could start by picking places that genuinely interest me or that are highly recommended, so there's something to look forward to each week.

That sounds like a thoughtful approach. By choosing places that interest you, exploring can become an exciting part of your routine. And by reaching out individually to classmates, you might find some shared enthusiasm for the study group. Remember, it’s all about taking these small, manageable steps that can lead to bigger changes. You’ve got a solid plan in place, and it’s really encouraging to see your commitment to this process. 

As your next step, you could try reaching out to one or two classmates to start and see how that goes, and perhaps choose a new spot to explore this week. Keep in mind, it’s perfectly okay to go at your own pace. You’re doing great, and I’m here to support you along the way.
Thanks, I'll give it a shot and see how it goes. I guess I'll start with reaching out to a couple of classmates and go from there.

client: Hey. I've been feeling really lonely and having a hard time adjusting to being in a new city for my grad program. It's just been tough without much social interaction due to the pandemic.

concern: I have never been in an academic setting that challenged me so much. In undergrad I was always on top of my work and had enough time to enjoy myself, go to the gym, and even party. In my second year of my PhD program all I do is work and on the weekends I usually sleep or go out somewhere just to try to enjoy myself. Now that the semester has begun I lost my Sundays to a full day of class work. I am so lucky to do what I love, but I love it a lot less when I am being overworked. It does not help that my PI is an absolute workaholic. How do people not burn out working 6 days a week with such mentally involved tasks?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm glad you're here today. What's been on your mind lately?
I've been feeling really overwhelmed with my workload in my PhD program. It's just been tough balancing everything and keeping my stress levels in check.
therapist: It sounds like you're juggling a lot right now, and it's weighing heavily on you. Could you tell me more about what's been particularly challenging for you?

client: It's just the sheer amount of work and the pressure to always be on top of things. There's never a moment to just breathe, you know? My weekends are swallowed up too, so it feels like there's no end in sight.
Therapist: That sounds incredibly exhausting. I'm wondering, if things were different and you had more balance, how do you imagine that would impact your life?
If I had more balance, I'd probably feel less like I'm constantly in survival mode. I'd have more time for myself, which I think would help me enjoy my work again and just feel happier overall.
Therapist: It sounds like having more balance could really enhance your well-being and enjoyment of your work. What do you think might help you start moving towards that balance you're envisioning?

I'm not entirely sure, but I think setting better boundaries with my work might help. Maybe I need to be more strict about my downtime and not let work bleed into every part of my life. It's just hard with the pressure to always be on top of things.

Based on what you've said, possible options could include setting specific times for work and downtime or finding ways to communicate your boundaries at work. What do you think might be a good first step for you to start setting those boundaries?

I guess I could start by setting specific work hours and trying to stick to them as much as possible. Maybe I could also try to have a conversation with my PI about my workload, although that seems kind of intimidating.

Those sound like thoughtful steps. We can look at setting specific work hours as the first actionable goal. As for talking with your PI, we can explore ways to prepare for that conversation to make it feel less daunting. What do you think about starting with setting work hours, and then planning how to approach the discussion with your PI?

Yeah, that sounds like a good plan. I think having a set schedule to follow will help me feel a bit more in control of things. And if we can work on how to approach my PI without it being super awkward, that’d be great too.

Great! You've taken some really proactive steps here. Establishing those work hours is a fantastic way to reclaim a bit of control and create personal time for yourself, which is so important. And when you're ready, we can definitely work on how to approach that conversation with your PI to make it as comfortable as possible for you. Remember, it's all about taking it one step at a time. You're making thoughtful decisions toward balance, and that's truly commendable. Between now and our next session, try to note any times you stick to your schedule successfully or any feelings that come up around your workload. I'm here to support you through this process.
Thanks, I appreciate the support, and I'll try to keep track of how things go with my schedule. I hope I can actually stick to it!

concern:
Will be having my Master's Thesis proposal defense in the morning, and I'm all a bit tense and anxious and nervous and all the things that have going through my head. 

Been sleepy all day as if this is a way for me to cope with the stress it causes. Wish me luck everyone, good luck also to the countless graduate students who will be defending their own works!


Update: 

I cant believe it's done! I passed the proposal defence. Now I cant rest for a week from .

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm glad you're here today. What would you like to discuss or explore in our session together?

Hey, thanks. I just had my Master's thesis proposal defense recently, and the whole process left me feeling really anxious and drained. Even though it's over, I'm still feeling the aftermath, you know?
therapist: It sounds like the thesis defense was quite an intense experience for you. What do you think is keeping that feeling of anxiety lingering?

client: I think it's just the whole build-up of stress leading up to it. Maybe it's also that I put so much pressure on myself to succeed, and now that it's done, I'm not sure how to just switch off and relax.

It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of pressure to succeed, which is understandable after such a significant event. How do you see your life changing if you were able to find a way to relax and ease that pressure?

client: If I could relax and ease the pressure, I think I'd feel more at peace and be able to enjoy things more. It's like I've been in this constant state of 'what's next,' and I'd love to just appreciate the moment without worrying so much.

It sounds like finding ways to relax and be present in the moment is important to you. Based on what you've shared, possible options to consider might be setting aside specific relaxation time or exploring activities that help you unwind. How do you feel about creating a goal around this, and what might be some first steps you’d like to take?

client: That sounds like a good idea. I think setting a goal for relaxation could help me be more intentional about it. Maybe starting with short daily breaks or finding a hobby that lets me disconnect might be a good first step.

Creating a goal for relaxation sounds like a promising step forward. Based on what you've said, options could include setting aside a specific time each day for a short break or exploring a new hobby to help you disconnect. How does creating an action plan with these steps sound to you, and do you foresee any challenges in implementing this?
Creating an action plan sounds helpful. I think my main challenge will be actually sticking to it and not letting other tasks or worries take over my relaxation time.

I'm really glad to hear that you're open to creating an action plan for relaxation, and it's perfectly normal to anticipate challenges. Let's focus on setting those short daily breaks and perhaps exploring a new hobby to help you unwind. Remember, it's all about small, manageable steps. If you find your other tasks creeping in, remind yourself that these breaks are an investment in your well-being and productivity. You've got this, and I'm here to support you every step of the way. Feel free to reach out whenever you need guidance or just want to talk things through. Keep being kind to yourself, and take it one day at a time.
Thanks, I appreciate your support. I’ll try to remember that these breaks are important for me.

concern:
Not sure if anyone else feels this way but it can be a lonely journey in grad school especially because of the niche stresses, things we have to deal with. 

Created a group me that will hopefully foster some community for people to talk with one another and build some friendships or the very least camaraderie 

Here’s the link to join: You're invited to my new group 'Grad School Community' on GroupMe. Click here to join: https://groupme.com/join_group/86601776/iTupsbUn

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! I'm glad you're here. Please feel free to share what's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
Hey, thanks for having me. I've just been feeling a bit isolated in grad school. It's like, even when I'm surrounded by people, the stress and workload make it hard to connect, you know?
That sounds really challenging. What do you think might change for you if you felt more connected during this time?

I think it would make a huge difference. Just having people to share experiences with, who understand what I'm going through, could really lighten the load. It would be nice not to feel so alone in all this.

Based on what you said, it sounds like building connections with others might be something worth focusing on. Possible options could include joining a study group or attending social events organized by your program. How do these ideas sound to you, or is there another direction you'd like to consider?

Yeah, those are good ideas, but sometimes it feels like everyone else is just as busy or stressed out. I started a GroupMe chat for grad students to try and create a space where we can connect more easily. It’s still new, but I hope it helps.

It sounds like you've already taken a meaningful step by starting that GroupMe chat, and that's a fantastic way to create a space for connection. Building on that, perhaps you could set a goal to regularly engage with the group, maybe by organizing a casual meetup or study session. Remember, it's important to be patient with yourself and others as you build these connections. Don't hesitate to lean on this chat as a supportive resource. You're doing great, and I'm here to support you in any way you need. Feel free to reach out as things progress or if you want to explore more ideas.
Thanks, I'll try to keep that in mind. It's just hard to stay motivated when it feels like everyone’s so busy.

concern:
I graduated college less than a year ago (May 2022); and my undergraduate experience was already screwed up by COVID-19 - I was forced to skip out on a full year before returning to Senior year because the US did not allow international students to take hybrid classes and my university was not offering at least 3 in-person classes for me during the 2020 - 2021 lockdown. So I got to watch all my friends graduate without me; I did qualify for an accelerated Master's Program in Economics and I was accepted but I opted not to pursue it due to COVID-19 and feeling that I did not want to stay in Fordham for both undergraduate and graduate school.  


Anyway, I somehow managed to get a short-term contract at the World Bank since they hired people from around the world, and if I work for the World Bank in a full-time job for about 15 years I am eligible for permanent residency (green card). For all intents and purposes I really want to stay and live and build a life in the US (especially now with geopolitical events in SE Asia). The problem is that I don't have options for employment in the private sector because the H1-b process is absurdly random and difficult; and the World Bank and IMF have outright told me that I can't get a fulltime job without AT LEAST a Master's Degree (it's already brutally difficult for me to get even a short-term contract role, let alone a fulltime job); and even this employment is not guaranteed.  


I'm thinking of getting a Master's Degree in Statistics or Data Science (an MBA or Master's degree in economics isn't very helpful) but I have checked that I did not take enough undergrad courses in Math or Computer Science to qualify (at least in the US). I'm fairly certain that my math skills and coding skills are nowhere near good enough for grad school (I struggled for a 3.60 gpa even before COVID-19)  
I'm honestly totally lost because I'm being forced to prepare for grad school so soon, just after I managed to find something solid career-wise (I'm 23 turning 24). Otherwise I have to go back to the Philippines and I probably won't have an opportunity to immigrate elsewhere anymore.  


Any advice for my circumstances?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm glad you're here. Please feel free to share whatever's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
client: Hey, thanks for having me. I'm just feeling a bit overwhelmed with my career and the future, especially with how everything's been since COVID hit.
It sounds like you're feeling quite overwhelmed with your career and future, especially given the impacts of COVID. Can you tell me more about what's been happening and how it's affecting you?

client: Yeah, it's like everything got thrown off track because of the pandemic. I had to miss out on a year of school, and now I'm struggling to figure out how to stay in the US and continue with my career.
It sounds like navigating these challenges has been really difficult for you. How do you see your career ideally moving forward, and what would life look like if things aligned with your goals?

client: I guess ideally, I'd love to land a stable job in the US, maybe at the World Bank or something similar, where I can grow professionally and work toward getting permanent residency. I'd feel settled and secure, and it'd be nice to finally plant some roots and stop worrying about the next visa or job.
That vision of stability and growth sounds like a meaningful goal for you. What are some of the steps you might consider taking to move closer to that ideal future?

client: I think I might need to look into grad programs that could boost my chances, even if it means going back to school sooner than I wanted. I'm also trying to network more and explore any opportunities that could lead to something permanent.

It sounds like you're considering a couple of avenues to achieve your goal. Based on what you said, options could include researching grad programs and actively engaging in networking. How do these options feel to you, and what would be a first step you might take in either direction?

client: Honestly, both options seem overwhelming right now. But I guess the first step might be to reach out to people I know in the industry and ask for advice on grad programs or job leads, just to get a clearer picture of my options.
Reaching out to your network for advice sounds like a practical first step. How would you like to go about this, and are there any specific people or resources you have in mind to contact?

client: I think I'll start with some of my former professors and colleagues from my internship. Maybe they can provide some guidance or even connect me with someone in the field. I’m also considering joining some professional groups related to economics or data science to expand my network.

That sounds like a solid plan. You've identified some great resources by reaching out to former professors and colleagues, and joining professional groups can really widen your network. Remember, taking things one step at a time can alleviate that overwhelming feeling. You're on the right track, and it's okay to move at a pace that feels comfortable for you. Keep nurturing those connections and exploring opportunities. You're doing really well, and I'm here to support you in this journey. Let's touch base again soon to see how you're progressing and to talk through anything new that comes up. Take care and keep moving forward!
Thanks, I'll try to keep that in mind. I guess I'll see how it goes and maybe we can catch up next time.
